issue.title: Backup wallet doesn't overwrite an existing file
issue.body: I don't know if it is a feature or a bug, but an error would be nice I guess.

events.body: Indeed, maybe I'll take a look tomorrow...
Ugh, this is bad if it is true, silently ignoring backup requests

I tried it and was able to overwrite the file. The modified stamp of the file got updated.

@Joukehofman Can you please give more details, OS, Bitcoin version and so on.

Ubuntu 10.10, bitcoind version 7.1 with this patch: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/2021#issuecomment-10472113

But according to the date, it also didn't work with versions 6.2 and 6.3
@Joukehofman I need to further ask, you tried to backup via bitcoind or the GUI one Bitcoin-Qt? I tried the Bitcoin-Qt dialog, which is working for me on Windows 7 x64.
I tried backupwallet RPC command via RPC console and that also works, I can't seem to reproduce on Windows.

One glitch I found is that RPC console converts this input `C:\Users\Diapolo\Desktop` into `C:UsersDiapoloDesktop` so it means to achieve what I want I need to escap back-slashes `C:\\Users\\Diapolo\\Desktop`.

@laanwj It would be nice to tell the use that fact in the welcome message?
I'm at 3ed1ccb0898b22353e9fcc942b43df98c9a3bf4c, and can confirm that 64-bit bitcoin-qt console on Ubuntu 12.10 is silently failing to overwrite files that exist.

@diapolo yes, you should surround paths with '' (single quotes). Otherwise
you get into trouble with spaces as well.

Can you guys try, if with #2044 the client at least shows an error. What boost versions are you using?

@laanwj I remember Gavins proposal to change the format of the RPC commands help messages... would make sense :).

The RPC overwrites fine for me.   I wonder if what is happening is that the behavior of backupwallet is confusing people and the wallet is being written someplace they don't expect instead of over the expected file?

Boost 1.46 here.

backupwallet /path/to/writeable-dir/non-writeable-file doesn't give an error, but
backupwallet /path/to/non-writeable-dir/file does.

backupwallet /path/to/non-writeable-dir/ doens't give an error message either, even though it would normally backup to /path/to/non-writeable-dir/wallet.dat
